facts.text: Appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 184 of 1956 from judgment and order dated October 15, 1956, of the former Nagpur High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION criminal Appeal No. 184 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 15, 1956, of the former Nagpur High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 205 of 1956 and Criminal Reference No. 15 of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated July 10, 1956, of the First Additional District Judge, Nagpur in Sessions Trial No. 34 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant Khushal convicted and sentenced to death under s. 302, Indian Penal Code, for pre-meditated murder of Baboolal on the night of February 12, 1956, in Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: is directed against the companycurrent judgment and orders of the companyrts below, so far as the appellant Khushal is companycerned, companyvicting and sentencing him to death under s. 302, Indian Penal Code, for the pre-meditated murder of Baboolal on the night of February 12, 1956, in one of the quarters of the city of Nagpur.

facts.text: Two rival factions in Mill area in Nagpur: appellant and Tukaram leaders of one, Ramgopal P.W.4, Inayatullah P.W.1, Tantu P.W.5 leaders of opposite.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there are two rival factions in what has been called the Mill area in Nagpur. The appellant and Tukaram who has been acquitted by the High Court, are the leaders of one of the factions, and Ramgopal, P.W. 4, Inaya- tullah, P.W. 1, and Tantu, P.W. 5, are said to be the lead- ers of the opposite faction.

facts.text: Before February 12, 1956, incidents between factions; Inayatullah and Tantu prosecuted.

anchor.surface_text: Before the time and date of the occurrence, there had been a number of incidents between the two rival factions in respect of some of which Inayatul- lah and Tantu aforesaid had been prosecuted.

facts.text: On February 12, 1956, Tantu and Inayatullah made reports about attacks by Khushal's party.

anchor.surface_text: Even on the date of the occurrence, apart from the one leading to the murder of Baboolal, which is the subject-matter of the present appeal, Tantu and Inayatullah had made two separate reports about the attacks on them by Khushals party.

facts.text: Sampat lodged report at Ganeshpeth police station at about 9.30 p.m. on February 12, 1956, against Inayatullah alias Kalia and Tantu for attack with sharp-edged weapons.

anchor.surface_text: There was another report lodged by Sampat-one of the four persons placed on trial along with the appellant, for the murder of Baboolal. That report was lodged at Ganeshpeth police station at about 9.30 p.m. on the same date-February 12, 1956-against Inayatullah alias Kalia and Tantu, that they had attacked the former with sharp-edged weapons  Ex. P- 26 .

facts.text: Khushal on bad terms with Baboolal who was friendly with opposite faction leaders.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that the appellant Khushal was on bad terms with Baboolal who was on very friendly terms with the leaders of the opposite faction aforesaid.

facts.text: Sampat, Mahadeo, Khushal and Tukaram attacked Baboolal with swords and spears at about 9 p.m. in narrow lane of Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: Being infuriated by the companyduct of Baboolal in associating with the enemies of the party of the accused, Sampat, Mahadeo, Khushal and Tukaram suddenly attacked Baboolal with swords and spears and in- flicted injuries on different parts of his body. The occur- rence took place in a narrow lane of Nagpur at about 9 p.m.

facts.text: Baboolal taken to Mayo hospital by father and others, reached at about 9:25 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Baboolal was taken by his father and other persons to the Mayo hospital where he reached at about 925 p.m.

facts.text: Dr. Kanikdale (P.W.14) questioned Baboolal who stated assaulted by Khushal and Tukaram with swords and spears, noted in bed-head ticket Ex. P-17.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor in attendance Dr. Kanikdale  P.W. 14  at once questioned him about the incident and Baboolat is said to have made a statement to the doctor which the latter numbered in the bed- head ticket  Ex. P-17  that he had been assaulted by Khu- shal and Tukaram with swords and spears.

facts.text: Doctor telephoned Ganeshpeth police station, information numbered at 9.45 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: After numbering the statement aforesaid, of Baboolal, the doctor telephoned to the Ganeshpeth police station where the information was numbered at 9.45 p.m.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector A.K. Khan recorded Ex. P-1, registered offence under s.307 IPC, went to hospital.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving the information, Sub-Inspec- tor A. K. Khan recorded Ex. P-1  and registered an offence under s. 307, Indian Penal Code, and immediately went to the Mayo hospital along with a head-constable and several company- stables.

facts.text: SI recorded dying declaration Ex. P-2 at 10:15 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, he actually recorded Baboolals statement in answer to the questions put by him  Ex. P-2  at 10-15 p.m.

facts.text: Magistrate M.S. Khetkar recorded dying declaration Ex. P-16 between 11:15 and 11:35 p.m., certified fit by Dr. Ingle.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, Shri M. S. Khetkar, a magistrate, first class, was called in, and he recorded the dying declaration  Ex. P-16  between 11-15 and 11-35 p.m. in the presence of Dr. Ingle who certified that he had examined Baboolal and had found him mentally in a fit companydition to make his dying declara- tion.

facts.text: Baboolal died next morning at about 10 a.m. in hospital.

anchor.surface_text: Baboolal died the next morning at about 10 a.m. in hospital.

facts.text: Appellant arrested four days later in out-house locked from outside on Seminary Hill in Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was arrested four days later in an out-house locked from out- side, of a bungalow on Seminary Hill in Nagpur.

facts.text: First Additional District Judge, Nagpur in Sessions Trial No. 34 of 1956, judgment July 10, 1956: convicted appellant and Tukaram under s.302 IPC, death to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After investigation and the necessary inquiry, four persons were placed on trial and the appellant was one of them. The Additional Sessions Judge acquitted two of them and companyvict- ed the remaining two the appellant and Tukaram-under s. 302. Indian Penal Code... He sentenced the appel- lant to death...

facts.text: High Court judgment October 15, 1956: acquitted Tukaram, upheld conviction and death sentence of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court, by its judgment and orders dated October 13, 1956, acquitted Tukaram... upheld the companyviction and sentence of the appellant... the reference made by the learned trial judge was accepted and his appeal dismissed.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) on ground of sufficiency of evidence and error re liquor case.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground for the grant of the certificate may be reproduced in the words of the High Court itself The main ground is that there is number enough evidence against the accused and that there is an error in our judg- ment in holding that there was numberevidence to show that Khushal...

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal in limine but examined merits and upheld conviction and death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we uphold the judgment and order of the High Court companyvicting the appellant of murder and sentencing him to death.

facts.text: Appellant absconding till arrested on February 16, 1956, in locked room at Ganesh dhobi at Hazari Pahar.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant companyld number be traced till February 16, 1956, on which day, the police obtained information to the effect that the accused had been companycealing himself in the premises of Ganesh dhobi at Hazari Pahar. He went there and found the appellant sitting in a room which had been locked from the front side.

facts.text: Dying declarations consistently named Khushal and Tukaram as assailants with sword and spear.

anchor.surface_text: The most remarkable fact which emerges from an examination of the three successive dying declarations made in the companyrse of about two hours, by the deceased, is that he company sistently named the appellant and Tukaram as the persons who had assaulted him with sword and spear.

holdings.text: The certificate of fitness granted by the High Court does not satisfy the requirements of Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these considerations, it has got to be held -that the certificate of fitness granted by the High Court does not satisfy the requirements of Art. 134 1  c  of the Con- stitution. The appeal on such a certificate has, therefore,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court granted certificate on sufficiency of evidence, a question of fact; cites precedents like Haripada Dey holding certificates improper for fact questions.

holdings.text: A conviction can be based solely on a dying declaration without corroboration if the court is satisfied of its truthfulness after scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to examine the legal position whether it is settled law that a dying declaration by itself can, in no circumstances, be the basis of a conviction... On a review of the relevant provisions... we have come to the conclusion... that it cannot be laid down as an absolute rule of law that a dying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction unless it is corroborated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reviews Evidence Act s.32(1), distinguishes from accomplice evidence under s.133/114(b), surveys High Court and Privy Council precedents, holds no absolute rule of law or prudence requiring corroboration.

holdings.text: The circumstances of the appellant's absconding can be used as corroboration of the dying declarations.

anchor.surface_text: corroboration in the subsequent conduct of the appellant in that, as deposed to by prosecution witness 31-the Sub-Inspector in- charge... The question whether the circumstances of the appellants alleged keeping out of the way of the police, for a number of days

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defence explanation of hiding due to liquor case rejected after examining records; absconding consistent with guilt in murder.

holdings.text: The three dying declarations made by Baboolal are reliable and truthful.

anchor.surface_text: The most remarkable fact which emerges from an examination of the three successive dying declarations made in the course of about two hours, by the deceased, is that he consistently named... Having made the general observations bearing on the question of the legality of basing a conviction on a dying declaration alone,... let us examine

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent naming of assailants, prompt recording, no tutoring, fit state certified, consistent with injuries, opportunity to identify.

holdings.text: There are no extenuating circumstances justifying a lesser sentence than death.

anchor.surface_text: The only other question that remains to be considered is whether there are any extenuating circumstances in favour of the accused justifying the lesser of the two sentences prescribed by law. In our opinion, there are none.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate cold-blooded pre-meditated murder; no favouring factors.

holdings.text: Oral testimony of eye-witnesses cannot be relied upon.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court was more pronounced in its view that the testimony of those four witnesses was not trustworthy. The High Court has discussed their evidence in great detail,...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partisan witnesses; High Court assessment accepted; not used even for corroboration.

holdings.text: The appellant is guilty of murder under s.302 IPC and sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we uphold the judgment and order of the High Court convicting the appellant of murder and sentencing him to death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dying declarations sufficient basis; corroborated by absconding; no doubt on reliability.

holdings.text: Dying declaration recorded by magistrate stands on higher footing than one depending on oral testimony.

anchor.surface_text: that a dying declaration which has been recorded by a competent magistrate in the proper manner, that is to say, in the form of questions -and answers, and, as far as practicable, in the words of the maker of the declaration, stands on a much higher footing than a dying declaration which depends upon oral testimony

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper recording reduces infirmities of memory and character.

holdings.text: Dying declaration not equivalent to accomplice evidence or confession requiring corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: Though under s. 133 of the Evidence Act, it is not illegal to convict a person on the uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice, illustration b to s. 114... The same cannot be said of a dying declaration because a dying declaration may not, unlike a confession, or the testimony of an approver, come from a tainted source.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dying decl has special sanctity; maker not inherently tainted like accomplice.

precedents.citation: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal 1 , to the effect that a High Court exceeds its power of granting a certificate of fitness under that article if the certificate discloses that the main ground on which it was based related to a question of fact

precedents.case_name: Haripada Dey v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court exceeds power granting certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) if based on question of fact
precedents.cited_holding: a High Court exceeds its power of granting a certificate of fitness under that article if the certificate discloses that the main ground on which it was based related to a question of fact

precedents.cited_proposition: To the same effect as Haripada Dey on certificates under Art. 134(1)(c)

precedents.case_name: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Convictions on dying declarations alone had been rested if true, but this decision required corroboration

precedents.citation: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh  1

anchor.surface_text: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh  1 , companytains the following observations, at p. 423, which have been very strongly relied upon, on behalf of the appellant

precedents.case_name: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: It is not safe to convict merely on dying declaration without corroboration
precedents.cited_holding: It is settled law that it is number safe to companyvict an accused person merely on the evidence furnished by a dying declara- tion without further companyroboration because such a statement is number made on oath and is number subject to cross-examination...

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Akbarali Karimbhai  I , that a statement which is companyered by s. 32 1  of the Evidence Act is relevant evidence and has to be judged on the same principles as other evidence

precedents.cited_proposition: Dying declaration is relevant evidence, weaker type, if part false other needs corroboration; no need to reject whole if part false

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Premananda Dutt  1  to the effect that it is number permissible to accept a dying declaration in part and to reject the other part

precedents.cited_proposition: Not permissible to accept dying declaration in part; stands on different footing from court testimony

precedents.citation: the King v. Maung Po Thi  2

anchor.surface_text: the King v. Maung Po Thi  2 . In that case, the positive evidence led on behalf of the prose- cution was found to have been tampered with and unreliable.

precedents.cited_proposition: Conviction can be based solely on dying declaration if it has impress of truth
precedents.cited_holding: no such rule of prudence requiring corroboration; if satisfied true, conviction on dying declaration alone

anchor.surface_text: In re, Guruswami Tevar  1   , delivered the unanimous opinion of the Court after examining the decisions of that High Court and of other High Courts in India.

precedents.cited_proposition: No hard and fast rule; if convinced true after considering circumstances, convict without corroboration
precedents.cited_holding: each case must be decided in the light of the other facts and the surrounding circumstances, but if the Court... is companyvinced that the statement is true, it is its duty to companyvict, numberwithstanding that there is numbercorroboration

anchor.surface_text: Mohamad Arif v. Emperor 2 , and of the Nag- pur. High Court in Gulabrao Krishnajee Maratha v. King Emperor 3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: To the same effect as Guruswami Tevar on dying declarations without corroboration

precedents.citation: Gulabrao Krishnajee Maratha v. King Emperor 3

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to examine the legal position whether it is settled law that a dying declaration by itself can, in no circumstances, be the basis of a conviction... On a review of the relevant provisions... we have come to the conclusion... that it cannot be laid down as an absolute rule of law that a dying declaration cannot form the sole basis of conviction unless it is corroborated.
